Message.Title: Battery Airworthiness Readiness Force will work !
Message.Msg: How will the BARF teams (Battery Airworthiness Readiness Force) working on the dumbest fix imaginable: adding hot gas manifolds to exhaust flaming battery debris overboard! I don’t get how this is going to lower the frequency of in flight emergencies. I think the same rule for Passengers, should also apply to Batteries. "No Smoking “It seems the solution is in containing the fire and reacting more efficiently to it than in preventing it in the first place. This path cannot end well. Not at all. Wall Street let this clown CEO McNerney destroy one of America's most important industrial icons through an ideology that thought the company can substitute engineering talent with a global supply chain. This cannot drag out for six to nine months ... from a financial standpoint." Oh yes it can....from a lifesaving standpoint, Mr. Boeing Bean counter. A host of "teams" in place draining huge quantities of resources and expenditures to fix the continuing failures of the management "team" perched atop their constructed pyramid of incompetence waiting for the next millions in bonus rewards for the same incompetence. Boeing is confident in the safety and reliability of lithium-ion batteries” So confident they have to engineer solutions to mitigate unsafe conditions presented by the batteries. Daunting financial forces, he dictates, are forcing his otherwise talented men and women to scramble, to work around the clock, to create special “flaming matter ejection tubes” to throw out (up) caustic and burning goo, lest it take down his special bird??? This story gets stranger and more depressing every day To "save" money, Boeing chose to scatter the design and integration of many systems across the globe, and chose not to test them before installing them into the 787 airplane. Now, Boeing is compelled to do the integration analysis and testing it should have done before the 787 took to the sky and became a fire starter. Wall Street let this clown CEO McNerney destroy one of America's most important industrial icon Well, yeah. Don't you know that engineering talent is cheap? You can outsource that to India and China. Those executives and number crunches are REALLLY important. Can't outsource those impotent executives . That's why they get those multi-million dollar bonuses for playing golf. So great, Boeing corporate is going to stick with the lithium ion battery no matter what. What's missing from the equation is who is going to fly the DREAMLINER? Ask the pilots UNION, that part of the system, wasn't outsourced. Didn't they say that any kind of fire on board an airplane was unacceptable? Sorry, but clearly the real winner here is Airbus. Boeing continues and maintains the same arrogance and hubris that created this problem, and the MANY problems that will follow. And, that hubris is a delusional belief that Boeing Corporate is so powerful that reality is what it (Boeing Coporate) edicts it to be. Actually, this works quite well, but only internally at Boeing. Sadly for Boeing, once one exits Boeing property the hard realities of REAL reality and the cold realities physics are not swayed by the edicts of Boeing Corporate. ERGO, if Corporate edicts that lithium-ion batteries will work, then by all the Gods and Zues-IT WILL. Airbus, at least, has the humility and good judgement to bow to reality and change battery type. Boeings hubris is quickly leading the company to the brink of irrelevance and failure. Ironic ! After roughly 15 years of following the "Stonecipher Doctrine" that "[Boeing is] not an engineering company", to what group do they turn to (attempt to) salvage the 787? Answer: the engineers! Not the MBAs, not the management and supply-chain theorists. Not the PowerPoint cowboys. The engineers. Please excuse me while I gloat. Of course, the senior corporate leadership that promulgated & perpetuated the "Stonecipher Doctrine" will not draw the obvious conclusion, because doing so would constitute an admission that they were wrong ... which would be professional leprosy. Message.Title: SPEEA Union votes on strike ,in a militant mood, due to insulting offers from the CEO
Message.Msg: Feb 18 (Reuters) – SPEEA a union of 23,000 Boeing Co engineers with buttons read "No Nerds, No Birds." Are set to vote for a strike. And they rarely strike. In nearly 70 years of representation, the members of the Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace have walked out on just two occasions for a total of 41 days - earning them a reputation for being pushovers in negotiations. But, the union has marched steadily, and with a new militancy, toward a strike that could affect how quickly Boeing can implement a fix to its grounded 787 Dreamliner. SPEEA Members are voting this week on whether to reject Boeing's latest contract offer and authorize a strike, as union leaders recommend. On Tuesday, the union will tally the votes. At stake is an estimated $200 million a month in cash that Boeing is losing by not delivering the 787, which is grounded until a fix for its burning battery problem is found and regulators approve it. A walkout by engineers also could slow or halt production on Boeing's other airplane lines for the 737, 777, 767 and 747, several of which have been speeded up to capitalize on a huge book of orders. . SPEEA has billed this strike as a low-risk way to get Boeing back to the bargaining table The sticking point is Boeing's insistence on putting new hires into a defined-contribution retirement plan instead of the traditional pension SPEEA members have. SPEEA said the new plan pays 40 percent less over a 30-year career, Boeing is living through a modern-day gold rush, except the 787 and the 747. High oil prices and easy financing have spurred airlines to order record numbers of new, fuel-efficient planes. Boeing is speeding up its factories to deliver them as fast as possible. The CEO gave himself a 34% pay raise and has a defined pension of 22 million dollars fully funded, while the CEO started by cutting the pay of the engineers to less than the last contract on the first best and last offer and then offered a less #$%$ slightly better pay, to make a comparison offer, and expects the workers who are the best workers in the world, to not see this ploy and wants to make offer even less the benefits for the workers and it does not sit well .

Topic.Title: Battery Fix As I Predicted

Message.Msg: I agree LI batteries are a fire hazard, and BA should have treated them as if catastrophic failures are to be expected by incasing them in a case the can 100% contain the fire, and vent the fumes outside the aircraft from day one. Also I think BA under estimated the task of keeping a LI battery with 10 cells operating safely. The fact is the more cells a LI battery has the harder it is to keep one cell from going into an unsafe condition. This is why cell phones which use a single cell LI battery hardly ever go up in smoke compared to laptops which use 3 to 4 cell LI batteries despite the fact there are way more cell phones. Also as the battery size gets larger, the chance of it going up in flames grows from failures, another reason a laptop LI battery is for more prone to a failure induced fire. I do think LI batteries can be made safe enough for aircraft use, but containment is only part of the solution. BA needs to go back to the drawing board, and completely redesign the battery management system. This time it needs to monitor every aspect of every cell it the battery. Voltages, temperatures, charging rate, discharge rates, charge capacity, of each cell in the battery. So that a failing cell can be detected early enough that the battery can be removed from service before it has a major failure. The big question is by the time you add the weight of the containment system, the more sophisticated battery management system, and the added cost, are the LI batteries still cost effective?

Message.Title: new battery means new certification process, more time delay , forget safety , follow the money
Message.Msg: "Why doesn't Boeing switch to other batteries?" The reasons are many. First , and of the greatest importance, switching the battery system causes a loss of Aircraft Model certification basically starting the entire process over pushing the re-launch back anywhere from 10-24 months. Second, Boeing Management would have to assume even a hint of responsibility for this debacle, and THAT is simply unacceptable, it would be professional leprosy T. Wilson once said "Management is the art of getting things done in spite of the system". It occurs to me that the 787 debacle is an instance of the reverse: the system triumphing over getting things done. That is the essence of bad management Boeing executives failed to understand the risk of the outsourcing model for aerospace engineering and why it was a bad idea, blinded in part by the illusion of reduced costs ($). Then when the outsourcing model failed, they directed engineers to fly around the world to fix the mess. These same leaders now fail to recognize the risk of an Engineering strike, in spite of all that has gone wrong, evidenced by their nickel-and-dime approach to the contract negotiations ($$). Now, in the midst of this crisis, these same leaders are desperately trying to salvage earnings ($$$) with a cockamamie workaround that won't pass muster with the flying public. It's time for the Executive Leadership to trust in the integrity of sound engineering to design a proper solution. The short-term financial blinders ($$$$) worn by Boeing's management team is what got them into this mess, risks losing their vital engineering talent and now seems to demonstrate to the world that they can't even see the risk to the company's integrity and reputation, let alone safety to the public. Sad day for Boeing shareholders when Boeing management continually states it believes in its products but constantly delays schedules and finds more problems. Shareholder revolt should become a priority. So Boeing does not know what causes the battery fires and the solution is to protect the plane from the next onboard fire perhaps while the plane is over water and hours from land, at night. Actually titanium does burn, while it does have a high ignition temperature, the internal jet engine parts are not titanium alloy where the hot gasses come into contact with the fan parts. So Boeing has a battery that cannot be put out of fire once started and is going to contain the out of control fire with a titanium box? It is difficult to extinguish Titanium which is already on fire, CO2, water and foam will only feed it with more oxygen. It also burns with a very high temperature (sometimes it is used in fireworks). Titanium has a melting point approximately 400°F above the melting point of steel. Boeings fix is like putting a fire shield around your child’s room so the fire does not spread, while your child is still in the room. You can exit the plane at 30000 feet and 600 mph one time only. what's interesting is the ability to correct the issue is already at hand and yet they refuse to implement such a fix. are these people really just that stupid? do you really think that the flying public is going to just step on the plane without thinking "i wonder if it will catch fire this flight" clearly that is the thought of every passenger, and pilot, as long as there are li-ion batteries powering the systems. Boeing Managers have choices and yet they have chosen the wrong what we are watching is the epic collapse of Boeing, in slow motion Contain and vent the fire outside of the aircraft? You’re kidding right?

Message.Msg: Carnival Cruise Lines needs to learn a lesson in public relations from the White House. First of all, never admit to any wrongdoing, even if the people you represent are knee-deep in s#!t. Cruise line customers, much like voters, are simply not qualified to understand what they are experiencing. They are obviously leaping to pessimistic conclusions about the reality around them. "Stop being so negative," urged Carnival Cruise Lines president Janus Jacobson. "People need to focus on the positive, and the cruise experience will be more rewarding." She then went on to explain that "you create your own reality" and that the only reason passengers were covered in s#!t is because "they brought that on board with them like baggage." It's the Law of Attraction, right? Thus, it's all the passengers' fault. Jacobson went on to explain away specific concerns that have been brought to her attention by sickened passengers who described barely surviving in "vile" conditions: • Those plastic bags handed out to passengers to defecate into are actually a new "green technology" known as "recycled food reclamation receptacles." • The mattresses strewn across the decks in a shantytown arrangement aren't any sort of negative vacation experience; it's actually all part of a new feature called "ocean-side camping." • Passengers aren't actually knee-deep in s#!t. Instead, they are enjoying yet another new feature of Carnival Cruise Lines called "composting at sea" where passengers get to see their own feces turned into compost to grow salad greens served on the next Carnival cruise! • The lack of food on the cruise is part of Carnival's new "surprise weight loss experience" designed to reverse the 10 - 15 pounds customers usually gain on a cruise. • The smell of smoke in the rooms, caused by the engine catching fire and burning up, was actually just an "delightful aroma of roasted coffee" that Carnival says was really coming out of the kitchen, not the engine room. • The lack of electricity and air conditioning is part of Carnival's new age "sweat lodge cleansing experience," complete with vomiting and near-death experiences, both of which are designed to induce "spiritual visions" and turn you into a master of enlightenment. As the Triumph docked this evening, Carnival Cruise Lines CEO Janus Jacobson declared victory for the passengers, saying, "This is the first cruise ever offered in which passengers actually lost weight rather than gaining it. People who want to lose weight will now be lining up to join our next cruise, featuring an all-you-can-eat parasite cleanse buffet with roasted black walnut hulls and castor oil." See, there's nothing so bad that it can't be explained away using the same logic that the federal government uses to report unemployment numbers or inflation. Heck, passengers should be thanking Carnival Cruise Lines for delivering such an unforgettable Gulf of Mexico cleansing experience

Message.Title: 10 year old arrested for Toy Gun Again
Message.Msg: Fingerprinted and arraigned and a second court date...this is not the first time this kind of thing has happenned. Although this seems to be one of the most extreme cases of children being disciplined over toy guns and gun gestures, it is far from isolated. As we have seen over the past few weeks, in the wake of the Sandy Hook shooting, it is now a daily occurrence. Ealier this month, a student in Florence, Arizona was suspended because he had a picture of a gun on his computer. At the beginning of the month, it was reported that a six-year-old kindergartner in South Carolina was suspended for taking a small transparent plastic toy gun to school for a show and tell. A day before that incident we reported on the five-year-old in Massachusetts who faced suspension for building a small toy gun out of lego bricks and play-shooting his classmates. We also reported on an incident that erupted when a discussion between two children about a toy nerf gun caused a lockdown and a massive armed police response at two elementary schools in the Bronx. In another incident, a Long Island high school was also placed on lock down for 6 hours in response to a student carrying a toy nerf gun. In yet another recent incident, a five-year-old girl was suspended after a three hour grilling, and described as a “terroristic threat” when she brought a pink bubble gun to school. A South Philadelphia elementary student was searched in front of classmates and threatened with arrest after she mistakenly brought a “paper gun” to school. A 6-year-old boy was suspended from his elementary school in Maryland for making a gun gesture with his hand and saying “pow”. Days after that incident, another two 6-year-olds in Maryland were suspended for pointing their fingers into gun shapes while playing “cops and robbers” with each other. In Oklahoma, a five-year-old boy was also recently suspended for making a gun gesture with his hand. And finally, a 13-year-old Middle School seventh grade student in Pennsylvania was also suspended for the same hand gesture.

Topic.Title: 10 year old arrested for Toy Gun Again

Message.Msg: Good thing I am not a child today doing what I routinely did when I was one. Running around wildly with my cap pistol wildly firing it with the rest of the kids in the neighborhood playing Indians and Cowboys. I almost always had a pocket knife with me almost every day in school, my favorite a military issue paratrooper switchblade with with integral parachute line cuter, and many teachers knew I had it, but those days their only concern was it becoming a distraction in class. The rule was keep it in your pocket during class, or have it confiscated until the end of the year. If that sounds bad enough, I would have fore sure run foul with the likes of the ATF, home land security, and the FBI, for doing what we considered fun back in those days. Like making acid bombs, which today are considered at the very least a destructive device, and by some a weapon of mass destruction. Which to us back then was a way to make a loud, but stinky bang. Yet I was a model child, never in trouble, and considered a good example, yet if I did what I did today I would likely be the youngest public enemy ever.

Topic.Title: "Hubris" - selling of the Iraq War

Message.Msg: Murrymom below is the Politifact summary of the Iraq war through 2010 which includes costs that are attributable to Obama after Bush left office. As you can see the amount is from the non-partisan CBO . As you can see Ombummer's ineffective stimulus cost more and by the time you add in Odrama's war costs in Iraq Afganistan and countries we aren't even at war with like Pakistan, Cornel West's 'war criminal' Obama has outspent Bush by a country mile and MSNBC are on an acid trip if they are claiming $3 trillion in costs. ________________________________________________ From Politifact: Did the stimulus cost more than the war in Iraq? Washington Examiner editorial page editor Mark Tapscott warned readers Aug. 23, 2010, to expect to hear a lot from Democrats about the cost of the Iraq War. It might be expensive, he said, but not as expensive as President Barack Obama’s economic stimulus. Citing data from conservative writer Randall Hoven, Tapscott said, "Obama’s stimulus, passed in his first month in office, will cost more than the entire Iraq War -- more than $100 billion more." Really? Could the nearly seven-year-long war cost less than the 2009 stimulus, which was designed to keep the U.S. economy from sliding into a depression? (actually the depression ended in June 2009) At first glance, the numbers look pretty close. The most recent figures from the Congressional Budget Office, released in August 2010, put the total cost for the stimulus -- from February 2009 through 2019 -- at $814 billion. Estimated funding for the war in Iraq totals $709 billion from 2003 to 2010, according to the same CBO report. As for the war cost, we found a variety of opinions on the total. Some reports have higher estimates than the CBO’s for that same time period. A July 2010 report from the Congressional Research Service estimated the cost at $748 billion, which includes costs for the military, the State Department and foreign aid, and Veterans Administration medical costs related to the war. Add in supplemental appropriation from 2010, and you get about $750 billion, said James R. Horney, director of federal fiscal policy at the Center for Budget and Policy Priorities, a left-leaning group that studies tax and fiscal issues. Another expert on defense spending told us it’s also important to account for inflation. "The cost of the Iraq War going back seven years and the cost of the stimulus act through 2019 cover a broad stretch of time over which inflation becomes important," Todd Harrison, a senior fellow for defense budget studies at the Center for Strategic and Budgetary Assessments, said in an e-mail. The center is a think tank that focuses on defense issues. Adjusted for inflation, the cost of the Iraq War to date totals $756 billion and the stimulus act totals about $820 billion, according to Harrison.
